message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation shows a monoclonal protein peak indicating a possible diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Whole-body CT scan is the most appropriate next step to establish the diagnosis as it can detect any bone lesions associated with multiple myeloma. Bone densitometry is not relevant to the diagnosis, rectal biopsy is not needed, and echocardiography does not help in diagnosing multiple myeloma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation shows an M protein band, indicating multiple myeloma. A whole-body CT scan is the most appropriate next step to establish the diagnosis and determine the extent of bone involvement. Bone densitometry, rectal biopsy, and echocardiography are not helpful in diagnosing multiple myeloma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation results suggest the possibility of multiple myeloma. Whole-body CT scan is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of the disease. Bone densitometry is used to evaluate bone density, which is not relevant in this case. Rectal biopsy is used to diagnose amyloidosis, which is not the primary suspicion in this case. Echocardiography may be used to assess cardiac function, but it is not the most appropriate next step for establishing the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation shows monoclonal gammopathy, which raises suspicion for multiple myeloma. Whole-body CT scan is the most appropriate next step to establish the diagnosis and evaluate for any lytic lesions. Bone densitometry is useful for diagnosing osteoporosis, which is not a suspected diagnosis in this case. Rectal biopsy is used to diagnose amyloidosis, which is not the most likely diagnosis in this case. Echocardiography is not useful for diagnosing multiple myeloma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation shows an M spike, which is indicative of multiple myeloma. A whole-body CT scan can be used to confirm the diagnosis, and it is the most appropriate next step. Bone densitometry is not useful for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Rectal biopsy is used for the diagnosis of rectal cancer, and echocardiography is not useful for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation shows a monoclonal gammopathy, which raises concern for multiple myeloma. Whole-body CT scan is the most appropriate next step to look for signs of myeloma bone disease. Bone densitometry is not helpful in diagnosing myeloma. Rectal biopsy is not indicated in the workup of multiple myeloma. Echocardiography is not necessary at this point and will not aid in the diagnosis of myeloma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation detects a monoclonal band in the gamma region, indicating a possible multiple myeloma. Whole-body CT scan is the most appropriate next step to establish the diagnosis as it is used to detect bone lesions and any other organ involvement. Bone densitometry measures bone mineral density and is not specific to this patient’s presentation. Rectal biopsy and echocardiography are not relevant to the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation indicates the presence of a monoclonal protein or M protein, which suggests possible multiple myeloma. A whole-body CT scan can help to determine the extent of bone involvement, which is common in multiple myeloma. Bone densitometry is not appropriate as it does not directly help diagnose multiple myeloma. Rectal biopsy and echocardiography are also not relevant to this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation shows a monoclonal spike in the gamma region, which is suggestive of multiple myeloma or another monoclonal gammopathy. A whole-body CT scan is the most appropriate next step to assess for skeletal lesions that would support the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Bone densitometry and echocardiography are not helpful in establishing the diagnosis, and rectal biopsy is not indicated in this context.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation showing an M spike suggests the possibility of multiple myeloma. A whole-body CT scan is the most appropriate next step to establish the diagnosis as it can detect bone lesions, which are a common finding in multiple myeloma. Bone densitometry is used to measure bone density and is not helpful in diagnosing multiple myeloma. Rectal biopsy and echocardiography are not relevant to this case.
